metadata.title: Iliopsoas Syndrome
synonyms: iliopectineal bursitis. snapping hip syndrome (coxa saltans) is an associated condition
anatomical location body part affected: The anterior hip capsule/iliopsoas bursa lies deep to the iliopsoas tendon and runs from the inguinal ligament to the lesser trochanter. It is bordered medially by the femoral vessels and laterally by the femoral nerve. The bursa is bound anteriorly to the overlying iliopsoas musculotendinous junction and posteriorly to the fibrous hip capsule
description: Iliopsoas syndrome is characterized by musculoskeletal pain in the hip area, anterior thigh, and/or groin region. Conditions that can contribute to symptoms include bursitis, tendinitis/tendinosis, snapping tendon, muscle tears, and avulsion injuries
Iliopsoas tendinobursitis is an appropriate synonym because both the iliopsoas bursa and tendon are often inflamed(1)

Conservative treatment includes relative rest, thermal modalities (ice or heat), stretching (e.g., hip flexors, quadriceps, hamstrings), strengthening (gluteal muscles, hip rotators), and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory  drugs (NSAIDs)(1,2)

ICD-10 codes.M76.8: other enthesopathies of lower limb, excluding foot (use optional subclassification code 5 to indicate pelvic region and thigh as site of involvement) (ICD codes are provided for the readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: An aggravating activity, often overuse, is commonly identified
Exercise-related  pain in the inguinal area may radiate from anterior thigh to knee
Episodic discomfort is noted with daily activities, such as putting on socks and shoes in a seated position
Pain acutely increases with loaded hip flexion (fast walking, running, and climbing stairs or hills); however, pain usually subsides immediately after stopping exercise
Some patients report an occasional snapping sensation in the affected hip area
Tenderness is sometimes felt over the proximal medial femur near the femoral triangle Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: In the absence of direct trauma, this syndrome may develop insidiously secondary tooveruse of hip flexors during eccentric actions (e.g., full sit-ups  or straight-leg  raises,running uphill, soccer, rowing)
Inflammatory conditions that promote effusion in the hip joint (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis)(3)
Impingement of the prosthetic cup on the iliopsoas tendon after total hip arthroplasty (THA)(4)
pathogenesis: Iliopsoas syndrome results from synovial inflammation and hypertrophy of the bursal wall and/or irritation of the iliopsoastendon sheath

Excessive friction/compression of the conjoint iliopsoas tendon likely irritates the underlying bursa. This type of irritationmay worsen with:–increased tightness of the iliopsoas muscle–valgus stress on the hip joint (in abduction and medial rotation)–eccentric overuse of the iliopsoas to dampen ballistic hip extension (as in using a step machine or the sport of rowing)
In many cases, iliopsoas tendinitis probably develops concurrently with iliopsoas bursitis. Consequently, specific treatmentfor the tendon may be required(2)
Chronic iliopsoas tendinobursitis can develop into tendinosis, a noninflammatory degenerative condition that can indicateusing manual tissue mobilization once the bursitis is controlled
Intraarticular conditions that promote effusion may cause iliopsoas syndrome if the iliopsoas bursa communicates with thehip capsule(3)

Snapping hip syndrome (coxa saltans) is an associated condition that is usually asymptomatic. The snapping effect resultsfrom the iliopsoas tendon rubbing over the anterior inferior iliac spine, iliopectineal eminence, or bony ridge on the lessertrochanter
risk factors: Inflammatory conditions of the hip (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis or osteoarthritis)
Hip trauma or pathology causing medial instability of hip joint
Numerous sports and recreational activities that involve extreme valgus stress on the hip joint, including soccer,(2,5)dance,(6) rowing, track and field events, and gymnastics
Running hills and regular use of stairs or step machines for exercise

Intrinsic factors that might contribute to valgus stress on the affected hip; e.g., leg length discrepancy (long side moreoften symptomatic), tight iliotibial band, weak abductors and rotators of the hip, subtalar hyperpronation, and lumbopelvicdysfunction

overall contraindications precautions: Unusual findings suggestive of coexisting pathology that call for caution and physician consultation include an observable hip or pelvic deformity, swelling, redness or warmth, a palpable inguinal mass, capsular pattern of restriction, lumbar or sacroiliac dysfunction, groin pain that radiates to the hip joint, and partial weight bearing on ipsilateral leg
Frequent painful hip snapping requires further evaluation to exclude intraarticular pathology, such as disrupted labrum, subluxation, or torn ligamentum teres
Consult physician in case of hip trauma and persistent significant pain at rest and restricted ROM or difficulty bearing weight on affected leg
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When did the patient’s symptoms begin? Did direct trauma precede symptoms? Can the patient identify an activity that aggravates symptoms? In general, are symptoms getting better, getting worse, or staying the same?

course of treatment.medical management: May have included rest and avoidance of aggravating activity NSAIDs  injection of the iliopsoas bursa or tendon with corticosteroidreported to decrease pain and improve function in a patient who developed iliopsoas tendinitis after THA(7)
surgical management: Surgical management: Arthroscopic release of the iliopsoas tendon if conservative measures failed. A central compartment release or release at the lesser trochanter produced positive outcomes for those with snapping hip syndrome(13)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed and whether they are being taken
diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis is usually made clinically; however, ultrasonography, arthrography, or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may be required to exclude other potential causes of symptoms (e.g., avascular necrosis)(8)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document if pain is associated with certain daily activities, such as putting on socks and shoes, high-knee lift, and sports (see Risk factors , above)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Patients usually report the gradual onset of exertional pain and tenderness in the hip/inguinal area without discomfort at rest or morning stiffness
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to this condition
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia). Patient may report (and also demonstrate) an audible but not necessarily painful snap/pop with forced hip extension, abduction, and lateral rotation Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Did the patient have a hip condition or prior trauma to the involved hip? Has the patient been treated for a lumbar spine problem? Did the patient have a THA?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: (e.g., does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?) Symptoms may be directly associated with certain sports or occupational activities, or recently increased physical activity
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient report any disability in ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? If applicable, document presence of stairs, number of floors in home, and availability of caregivers

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive mobility devices are rarely indicated for uncomplicated iliopsoas syndrome
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance reactions, as indicated, and assess single limb stance and compare bilaterally
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses in the affected limbAssess for increased pain with resisted hip flexion (at 90° hip flexion). Pain in the proximal anterior thigh suggests irritation of the iliopsoas tendon and bursa, but also possible involvement of the associated lumbar nerve roots and hip joint
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Check for shortened stride length on the affected side –The patient may attempt to position the affected hip in flexion and external rotation to limit pain. Stride length may be shortened to avoid pain with extension(9)Assess hip joint mobility, as well as pelvic joints and lumbar spine
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Using manual muscle testing (MMT) –Assess strength of iliopsoas in seated position with hips and knees at 90°; complete iliopsoas tear is indicated if patient cannot raise thigh –Assess strength of the hip external and internal rotators, which are commonly weak in this syndrome(1) –Assess relative strength of hip extensors in prone position with 90° knee flexion and with knees extended, as gluteus maximus may be weak compared to hamstrings(1) –Assess strength and function of the hip abductors in standing
observation inspection palpation includi: Palpate for point tenderness at the iliopsoas bursa and for thickening of the iliopsoas tendon
Check for normal activation of the gluteus maximus in prone hip extension
Patients may have a palpable cystic mass that is tender to the touch(9)
Palpate for trigger points in the iliopsoas muscle
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Check for intrinsic factors that might contribute to hip valgus stress, such as leg length discrepancy (longer side more often symptomatic), muscular tightness, and subtalar hyperpronation –Assess tightness/flexibility of the iliopsoas and iliotibial band –Check for increased lumbar lordosis, which might result from shortened psoas muscle
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess hip ROM in supine, prone, and side-lying  positions. Note percentage of normal ROM at onset of pain and compare to unaffected leg. If hip ROM is pain-restricted,  there should not be a capsular pattern to the restriction –Assess ROM of lumbar spine and throughout lower extremities –Does passive hip hyperextension increase pain?Evaluate extent of disability reported in daily activities, such as putting on socks or walking upstairs or hills
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Test for pain on compression of bursa with overpressure in hip flexion, adduction, and lateral rotation –Increased valgus stress on the affected hip is often associated with positive results for Patrick’s test, Trendelenburg test, Piedallu’s sign, and/or Ober’s test –Examples of tests used in the assessment of general hip dysfunction(10) -Erichsen’s test -Used to detect signs/symptoms of sacroiliac (SI) disease and early spondylitis arthritis -Examiner holds iliac crests and presses together; the test is positive if pain is felt -Ludloff’s sign -Used to detect signs/symptoms of a traumatic separation of epiphysis of lesser trochanter -Ecchymosis will be present at the base of the femoral triangle, and the patient is unable to raise his or her thigh while seated -Ober’s test -Used to detect contracture of the iliotibial fascia -The patient lies on nonaffected side with knee and thigh flexed; the affected lower extremity is positioned in hip abduction, hip extension, and knee flexion; the affected lower extremity is then lowered to the table -The test is positive if extremity remains abducted  -Patrick’s (FABER) test -Used to detect restriction in ROM in the hip (may be caused by hip or SI joint pathology, or spasm) -Lateral malleolus is placed on opposite knee while patient is in supine; clinician then gently lowers the extremity while keeping the malleolus on the opposite knee -The test is positive if the extremity does not lower to the same level as the extended extremity -Trendelenburg test -Used to detect gluteus medius weakness or congenital hip joint dislocation -The patient stands on the affected lower extremity and raises the nonaffected extremity (lifts foot from floor) -The test is positive if hip (of the raised extremity) drops -Thomas test -Used to detect flexion contracture of the iliopsoas muscle -The patient is in supine; both extremities are brought to the chest; one extremity is lowered to the table while keeping the lumbar spine flat (no lordosis) -The inability to fully extend the hip may indicate a contracture

contraindications precautions: Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the pelvis, abdominal and lumbar regions during pregnancy
Ii an area with infection or bleeding
if a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
in the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
over the heart, stellate or cervical ganglia
Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use:(11)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Iliopsoas syndrome/pain, reduced strength and ROM, disability in ADLs, including sports
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Hip pointer (i.e., iliac contusion) Groin strain Ischiofemoral impingement Sports hernia Femoral stress fracture(9) Soft tissue tumor(9) Neuritis Femoral nerve compression (may be caused by iliopsoas bursitis) Meralgia paresthetica Referred hip pain (potentially from pelvic, intraabdominal, or retroperitoneal disease) DVT in groin or thigh Aseptic necrosis (rare in adults unless fracture or sickle cell disease is present) Femoral neck fracture Avascular necrosis Labral tear(9) Gynecological pathology
prognosis: Current opinion is that symptoms related only to iliopsoas tendinobursitis will resolve with conservative treatment and most patients will return to prior functional status(1,2)
Activity modification to avoid aggravating factors improves prognosis(1,2)
other considerations: Although treatment for iliopsoas syndrome is primarily noninvasive, ultrasound-guided  corticosteroid injection may be tried in resistant cases(12)
Interventions should address coexisting hip joint pathology or postural dysfunction that stresses the hip or lumbar spine
treatment summary: Evidence is lacking to support a specific therapeutic protocol for iliopsoas syndrome

Interventions to consider are relative rest; activity modification to avoid provocation of symptoms; patient education for prevention of training errors; pain management; manual therapy; therapeutic exercises for strengthening and stretching to fix faulty mechanics and muscle imbalance; and posture correction to control hip valgus stress

Arthroscopic release of the iliopsoas tendon indicates good results for those patients experiencing iliopsoas impingement syndrome resulting from a THA(14) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Pain and inflammation Eliminate/decrease pain _ _ Decrease inflammationActivity modification Restrict walking/ running up hills or stairs and modify aggravating exercises in patient’s training program, such as for soccer, dance (ballet), gymnastics, or rowing _ _ Promote low-impact cross-training (cycling, elliptical trainer, water running, or swimming) until pain resolves _ _ Physical agents/ mechanical modalities _ Ice pack/ice massage for painN/A Patient education on pain management and activity modification ROM deficits _ _ Inflexible/tight iliopsoasIncrease/maintain full hip ROM and flexibility of involved musclesManual therapy _ Mobilization of iliopsoas tendon followed by assisted stretching of hip flexors _ _ Physical agents/ mechanical modalities _ Ultrasound or heat pack to increase tissue elasticity prior to manual therapy and stretchingTherapy should progress as indicated and appropriate until ROM is restoredExercises may be prescribed for home, as appropriate Strength deficits in iliopsoas and hip rotatorsIncrease/maintain iliopsoas and hip rotator strengthTherapeutic exercises _ Progressive, multidirectional hip strengthening and flexibility program. Place special emphasis on stretching iliopsoas and strengthening the iliopsoas, hip rotators, and possibly the gluteus maximus and gluteus mediusExercises should progress as appropriate until strength deficits are resolvedHip rotator strengthening program with elastic resistance band(1)  Shortened stride length _ _ Altered weight-bearing status in severe casesNormalize stride length _ _ Return to full and equal weight-bearingGait training _ Once pain has been successfully managed, the clinician may incorporate gait training, as indicated _ _ Encourage contraction of the gluteal muscles with gait to improve hip stability(1)Progress each unique patient as indicated and appropriateRecommend activities for home that address gait deviations, as indicated and appropriate Postural dysfunction (leg length discrepancy, iliac rotation, subtalar hyperpronation, increased lumbar lordosis)Normalize posture, as ablePhysical agents/ mechanical modalities _ Posture correction (iliac rotation, lumbar lordosis, leg length discrepancy, hip drop) with manual therapy and application of devices (foot orthotics, heel lift), as indicatedProgress each unique patient, as indicated and appropriateRecommend activities for home that address postural deviations, as indicated and appropriate Decreased functional capacityRestore prior functional capacity in daily activities and/or sportsFunctional training _ Address ADLs, work- or sport-related deficitsProgress each unique patient, as indicated and appropriateProgressive exercises may be prescribed for home, as appropriate At risk for reinjury Decrease risk for reinjuryPatient education _ Patient education for independent care and prevention of reinjuryN/A Patient should be provided with written instructions on injury

desired outcomes: Increased hip ROM–Goniometry or inclinometer measurement for Thomas test
Increased iliopsoas, gluteal, and hip rotator strength–MMT
Normalized stride length–Reassessment of posture and gait
Return to full and equal weight-bearing  on the lower extremities
Normalized posture, as able–Reassessment of posture and gait
Restored prior physical functioning in daily activities and/or sports–Return to full activity without recurrent symptoms

maintenance or prevention: Maintain strength and flexibility of tissues that move the hip joint
Continue therapeutic interventions for underlying hip joint pathology
patient education: Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on December 18, 2015 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
